definition: the basic unit of all forms of life
the fundamental concept that all living things are made of cells which are the basic unit of structure and function and that cells come from pre-existing cells
thin flexible barrier that surrounds all cells regulating what enters and exits the cell
structure that contains the cell's genetic material often referred to as the 'brains' of the cell
organism whose cells have a nucleus 'eu' means true and 'karyo' refers to the nucleus (they truly have a nucleus)
unicellular organism that lacks a nucleus 'pro' means before 'karyo' refers to the nucleus (these came before the nucleus)
in eukaryotes, it's all the cellular contents outside of the nucleus; in prokaryotes, its all of the cell's contents
specialized structure that performs functions within eukaryotic cells
organelle that stores materials like water, salts, proteins, and carbs; often referred to as 'cellular tupperware'
organelle that breaks down substances (lipids, carbs, proteins) into smaller molecules that the cell can use; often referred to as the 'garbage men' of the cell
network of protein filaments in eukaryotic cells giving the cell shape and internal organization; helps in the movement and internal transport; often referred to as the 'cellular highway'
structure in animal cells that helps organize the cell division process (forms the mitotic spindle)
organelle made of RNA and protein found in the cytoplasm and on the rough endoplasmic reticulum (rER). Makes protein and is what makes the rER look rough
internal membrane system found in eukaryotic cells where components of the cell are assembled; comes in two varities: smooth (lipid making) and rough (protein making)

organelle in cells that modifies, sorts, and packagges proteins (and other materials) from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) for storage within the cell or release from the cell; often referred to as the 'UPS' of the cell
organelle found in plant cells (and some others) that captures light energy and converts it into chemical energy (site of photosynthesis)
a strong supporting layer surrounding the cell membrane of some cells (most commonly associated with plant cells)
flexibile double-layered sheet that makes up the cell membrane forming the barrier between the cell and its surroundings
property of membranes allowing some materials to pass across it but not others; also known as 'semi-permeable'
organelle that converts chemical energy from food into compounds that are convenient for the cell; often referred to as the 'powerhouse' of the cell
a process where particles move from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration (think spraying perfume in one corner of the room, does it just stay in that corner? No. It difuses.)
difussion of water through a selectively permeable membrane
when comparing two solutions, the two solutions have the same concentration are isotonic to each other
when comparing two solutions, this is the solution tha thas the higher concentration compared to the other
when comparing two solutions, this is the solution that has the lower concentration to the other
pressure that must be applied to prevent movement across a selectively permeable membrane
a type of diffusion that is made possible with the help (facilitation) of a protein channel
a channel protein within a cell membrane dedicated to the passage of water
the maintenance of a relatively constante 'stable' internal physical and chemical conditions
a group of cells that perform a particuluar function (muscle or epithelial are examples)
group of tissues workign together to perform related funtions
group of organs that work together to perform a function (examples: digestive or nervous)
on or in a cell, a specific protein to whose shape fits a specific molecular messenger (like a hormone)
